title: Who exactly is Ami and what does she have to do with BTS? - Quora

response.answer_text: OH MY GOD IM DYINGBSUSHDJSSJ-  Sorry for the bad word Ami????? Wait- WAIT- I THINK I KNOW- *goes to twiter* *searches bts*    Ah…  BAHAHHAHSAHAAHHAHSHAHAHAHAAHAAHHAHAHAHAAHHAAHHAHAH- *ahem* Google translate is not very good. And when I say that, I mean.. its AWFUL. Since it doesn’t know the writer, or who is receiving the message, many words, phrases, and ideas simply cannot be translated. Especially words that to many people mean something other than the literal translation. For example, army. To many people, it just means someone who fights in the military. But to many other people, it’s a meaningful name of a BTS fan. So, google translate has a difficult time processing this. To it, bts was just talking about the military. And I bet grammatically that throws everything off. So, sometimes it translates to Ami. Depending on what exactly they’re saying of course. No, bts isn’t dating some girl named Ami. No, their manager isn’t named Ami. They’re just talking to us :). Hope this helps! -Rey Sidenote: From the comments and rereading this answer, I realized that obviously “army” in Korean is probably just some random letters, or it means something random. Also, the mistranslation is caused by the fact that Korean doesn’t have an R, hence “ami”.  Oh my gosh, I think this is the most upvotes I’ve ever recieved! Over SEVEN HUNDRED upvotes and OVER 20K views??!? THANK YOU SO MUCHHHH!!!!!!!!! :))

“Ami” (아미) is BTS’s fandom name. Some translations just suck 😂 “Ami” is how BTS’s fandom name is written in Korean (ㅇ= silent,ㅏ = a, ㅁ = m, ㅣ= i, the easiest Korean letter to learn) I’m actually learning Korean rn. It’s written in blocks, and 1 block = 1 syllable. But there are rules. It must be written a certain way. This is how the blocks are in the word “아미”: 1 2 1 2 Number 2 in every Korean block must be a vowel. If a word starts with a vowel, the ㅇ will go in number 1, then the vowel in number 2. But the tricky part is that when the ㅇ is put last in a block with 3 characters, it makes a “ng” sound like in “walking”. Sorry I got carried away! I felt the need to explain why the ㅇ was silent because why not? Enjoy the mini Korean lesson and take care <3 ~Vanessa
